content: I mean, we're still naming their operations for crying out loud. Here's what I'm referring to: ++http://www.army.com/news/item/5067 I love these kinds of articles. It's always U.S. Commanders praising the Iraqis, when everyone knows that if we left tomorrow: -They would immediately abandon their posts. -They would sell all their equipment that we've paid for. -They would immediately ally themselves with a Shia or Sunni party depending on their preference. What a joke.

content: Interesting. In My time in Iraq First I spent 5 months with CJ-SOTF and watched the ICTF train up and execute missions. About the only thing I saw that they had a hard time with was Swimming(Drownproofing)- they seemed to fear the water, but the ODA's shoved 'em into the pool anyway, and they learned. One Night I watched them take down a Village through the LRAS and read the AAR, Seemed those Iraqi's Knew their Business. For the rest of my time, We worked with IA, IP, and ISP's IA Dogfaces had surprising abilities. One day on Dismounted Patrol in al-Ameriya a Jundi told Our MTT Lt. that they needed to check a certain house off of Ferris Wheel Road. The Jundi noticed a Hose running on the "Grass" with no one using it. He said with water so scarce you dont waste it. He insisted that the house be checked. a Search of the House revealed one Detainee hiding in a shed in the back 1 German Walther P-38 (AC40)with Shortened Barrel and "Silencer" (Wipe type) 1 Austrian M95 Rifle in 7.92mm with barrel replaced with full length "Silencer" of a Fairly decent Maxim design, topped with a Swarovski Scope. 1 SVD Dragunov with Soviet Night Sight 1 Iraqi Al-Kadesih SVD Copy 1 Yugoslav SKS with integral Grenade Launcher 15 Rifle Grenades (HE-Frag & HEAT) of Serbian Manufacture Pagers, Cell Phones, Wire on spools,Photographs of Patrols, Military Maps, Semtex, 60mm Mortar shells, & Copper Bowls that we know understand were for EFP's (EFP being relatively rare then). ISP's were tough SOB's rumored to be ex Republican Guards who took over the old Kuwaiti Embassy Complex as a COP. From there they patrolled on Foot, Pickup truck and with these bad boys: attacks went down about 40 % through their Battlespace in less than 1 month. they started Manning checkpoints 24/7 along Rte. Irish and VBIED/IED attacks dropped 60%. IP's? Mixed bag, just like flatfoots anywhere you have good and bad. I watched from an Overpass one night as the Major Crimes Unit compound had one hell of a firefight going with insurgents. We were forbidden to enter the battlespace to assist as it belonged to another US Unit which refused to send patrols or QRF(it being Night). Eventually, My Cdr. decided we had Radio and BFT trouble, we ignored the order, Mounted up and rolled north to their Compound. As we arrived the Insurgents beat feet. This is my experience with Iraqi Forces as an Infantryman, your mileage may vary.
